Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: A Timing Approach to Network Forensics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract:
Providing cyber security against attackers who penetrate the network, insider attackers, and non-malicious user errors or equipment failures is a formidable challenge for the scientific community. The investigator addresses problems in the area of network forensics that arise in packet-based communication of information. A key feature of the research approach is the use of timing as an under-utilized degree of freedom that provides rich statistical structure about the information dynamics. Using timing modality for performing network forensics has the advantage that it will not excessively perturb normal operation in packet networks where the information exchange is achieved via packet contents. A novelty of this research is the inclusion of causal inference. Human judgments about the likelihood of events and dependencies among variables is strongly influenced by the perception of cause-effect relationships. To extend the same decision making power, a man-made system must acquire the ability to process cause-effect relationships, rather than only assessing questions of statistical dependence. PI's objective is to understand causal influences between network flows using the timing modality.
The PI will embark on an ambitious multidisciplinary research program that targets both theoretical and practical fundamental problems in security. The main research endeavors undertaken by the PI are: (1) analysis and mitigation of queuing timing side channels that arise in presence of shared resources; (2) develop of causal inference metrics and algorithms for complex networks; (3) design of efficient compression and storage approaches for network flows using good compression codes for point processes; (4) design of network flow watermarks that will be inserted in packet timings and serve the dual purpose of providing data integrity as well as a means for network inference.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research funded by this proposal targeted both theoretical and practical fundamental problems in security and can be summarized as follows:

Thrust 1: Analysis and Mitigation of Timing Side Channels. We explored timing side channels that arise when a resource is shared among users. For instance, such a side channel is introduced by shared routing resources within packet­based networks, such as the Internet and showed a fundamental trade-off between delay and privacy.
Thrust 2: Network Forensics through Causality. Our approach to estimating and analyzing causal relationships in complex networks utilized point process models and tools from information theory and statistical estimation theory. Specifically, we proposed the use of directed information (DI) as a causality metric, developped provable good estimators for DI, and proposed efficient structure­ learning algorithms 

 Thrust 3: Compression of Network Flows. Network diagnostics and intrusion detection may require linking flows (for causal inference or statistical correlation) either on­line or off­line. We used our finding from Thrust 2 to acheive this goal

Thrust 4: Design of Timing­based Flow Watermarks for Traffic Analysis. Digital watermarking has been extensively studied as a method of ensuring data integrity in context of multimedia signals. Design of flow watermarks, however, is a particularly challenging problem as these watermarks must withstand networking effects such as jitter, deletions, and insertions. We proposed a class of network flow watermarks that were robust yet transparent.

These research thrusts were linked by the mutual goal of advancing the state of the art in network forensics and by the unifying thread of timing that runs through them all.

The proposed research resulted in several publications in flagships confernces and journals in Information Theory and Signal Processing venues. The students funded and trained though this project have since joined Academia and Industry.
